subject: Re: [junit] Re: Testing Private Methods
msgSnippet: So said  Steven Taschuk  on  2002-12-19 -------------------- ... Gregorian ... Calendar. ... what ... I will one day write an article about how this notion
messageBody:
So said Steven Taschuk on 2002-12-19 --------------------

>Quoth J. B. Rainsberger:
> [...]
>> Your class now does two things: it represents a date on the
Gregorian
>> Calendar and it parses a string into a date on the Gregorian
Calendar.
>> Really, you have two classes here. [...]
>> * Should the parser be concerned with validating the SEMANTICS of
what
>> it parses?
>
>An astute question. On reflection, I've decided to follow your
>suggestion of separating the parsing out to a separate class.
>(Indeed, certain parts of the parsing procedure are already
>factored out.) Thanks for the advice.

I will one day write an article about how this notion slapped me in the
face one day. I separated a RequestParser from the Request and life was
good again. Your situation gives me yet another example.

Now could you help me find time to write the article? :)

> [...]
>> Open/Closed principle, free of charge. Woo-hoo!
>
>Que?

1. Google "Open Closed principle"
2. Notice that you can add a Calendar-related feature (parsing from a
String representation) without changing the underlying Calendar class.
The core class is "closed". That's good.

J. B. Rainsberger,
President, Diaspar Software Services
